source: Grant Ward's scuffed shot put Town ahead before Luke Varney rolled the ball into an empty net after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Cole Skuse's long-range shot fell to Tom Lawrence, who capped the scoring with a calm finish into the corner. Rangers offered little in attack, but sub Sandro headed Tjarron Cherry's corner against the post late on. Ipswich had failed to score in seven of their previous 10 Championship games, but could have had plenty more, with Christophe Berra heading wide from six yards, and Skuse firing a volley straight at Smithies. The Rs have won only once in their last six matches away from Loftus Road, and rarely looked like improving that record in Ian Holloway's second game in charge. The win lifted Mick McCarthy's Ipswich up four places to 14th and above Rangers, who slipped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy: "The irony was that poor old Alex Smithies cost them the second goal which set us up to win as comprehensively as we did. He then kept it from being an embarrassing scoreline, but I'll take three. "With Luke Varney and also Jonathan Douglas, I knew what I was going to get - even though I bet some people weren't thinking that when they saw the teamsheet. Luke epitomised everything what I want in this team. "We have not been bristling with confidence. I have had a couple of rotten weekends after Rotherham and Nottingham Forest. But hopefully Ipswich can be a happier place than it has been." QPR boss Ian Holloway:  "I am sure everyone will say everything hinged on the second goal, but it shouldn't have. "The goal was a calamity and after that we were awful and it could have been four or five. "Everyone will blame my keeper but I won't as my defenders should have made an angle for him. Even with my legs, I would have ran back and tried to help him. "My players need to be mentally tougher as a group. I am disappointed with how we finished today. We have got to try and be a bigger, braver and more solid team." Match ends, Ipswich Town 3, Queens Park Rangers 0. Second Half ends, Ipswich Town 3, Queens Park Rangers 0. Attempt saved. summary: In this passage, Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0 in a Championship match. The goals were scored by Grant Ward, Luke Varney (after a QPR keeper's miscue), and Tom Lawrence. Ipswich had several other opportunities to score but failed to convert. QPR offered little in attack and had a late chance when Sandro headed a corner against the post. Ipswich had struggled to score in recent games, but this win lifted them up four places to 14th, while QPR slipped to 15th. Mick McCarthy, Ipswich's manager, praised his team's performance, particularly Luke Varney, while Ian Holloway, QPR's manager, criticized his team's mental toughness and defensive play. The passage also details several unsuccessful attempts at scoring by both teams.

summary: In a match between Ipswich Town and Queens Park Rangers (QPR), Ipswich Town won 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal for Ipswich Town, followed by Luke Varney's goal from an Alex Smithies miscued clearance. Tom Lawrence scored the third goal for Ipswich Town. QPR's Sandro headed Tjarron Cherry's corner against the post late on. Ipswich Town's manager, Mick McCarthy, praised Luke Varney and Jonathan Douglas for their performance. Despite QPR's Ian Holloway's criticism of his team's performance, Ipswich Town climbed four places to 14th in the Championship table.

Ipswich could have scored more, but QPR's Sandro hit the post late on. The result lifted Ipswich to 14th, above QPR, who struggled in attack and defense. Ipswich's manager praised his team's performance, while QPR's manager acknowledged their weaknesses and called for mental toughness.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 at home, with Grant Ward scoring the first goal from a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney's goal after a miscued clearance by QPR keeper Alex Smithies, and Tom Lawrence capping the scoring with a calm finish. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance and the win, which lifted them to 14th in the Championship table, while QPR boss Ian Holloway was disappointed with his team's display and criticized their mental toughness. The result extended QPR's winless streak to six away matches.

source: Grant Ward's scuffed shot put Town ahead before Luke Varney rolled the ball into an empty net after QPR keeper Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Cole Skuse's long-range shot fell to Tom Lawrence, who capped the scoring with a calm finish into the corner. Rangers offered little in attack, but sub Sandro headed Tjarron Cherry's corner against the post late on. Ipswich had failed to score in seven of their previous 10 Championship games, but could have had plenty more, with Christophe Berra heading wide from six yards, and Skuse firing a volley straight at Smithies. The Rs have won only once in their last six matches away from Loftus Road, and rarely looked like improving that record in Ian Holloway's second game in charge. The win lifted Mick McCarthy's Ipswich up four places to 14th and above Rangers, who slipped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy: "The irony was that poor old Alex Smithies cost them the second goal which set us up to win as comprehensively as we did. He then kept it from being an embarrassing scoreline, but I'll take three. "With Luke Varney and also Jonathan Douglas, I knew what I was going to get - even though I bet some people weren't thinking that when they saw the teamsheet. Luke epitomised everything what I want in this team. "We have not been bristling with confidence. I have had a couple of rotten weekends after Rotherham and Nottingham Forest. But hopefully Ipswich can be a happier place than it has been." QPR boss Ian Holloway:  "I am sure everyone will say everything hinged on the second goal, but it shouldn't have. "The goal was a calamity and after that we were awful and it could have been four or five. "Everyone will blame my keeper but I won't as my defenders should have made an angle for him. Even with my legs, I would have ran back and tried to help him. "My players need to be mentally tougher as a group. I am disappointed with how we finished today. We have got to try and be a bigger, braver and more solid team." Match ends, Ipswich Town 3, Queens Park Rangers 0. Second Half ends, Ipswich Town 3, Queens Park Rangers 0. Attempt saved. Grant Ward scored first for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney capitalizing on a mistake by QPR's keeper Alex Smithies. Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a composed finish. QPR struggled offensively, with Sandro's late header hitting the post being their best chance. Ipswich, who had struggled to score in previous games, missed several opportunities to increase their lead. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place, while QPR dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance and highlighted the impact of Smithies' error. QPR manager Ian Holloway criticized his team's mental toughness and defensive support for the keeper.
